English (United States)(en-US): What would happen if I were to drop from,\nlet’s say, the middle story of the bookshelf?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 책장의 가운데 칸 정도에서 내가\n떨어진다면 어떤 일이 일어날까?

English (United States)(en-US): You would go ‘boing’, like a beach ball.|You would scatter, like a bunch of pebbles.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 비치 볼처럼 도잉 튀어오를 것 같아.|조약돌처럼 자잘히 흩어질 것 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): My surface has viscosity but\nis not firm enough for that.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 표면은 점성이 있지만, 그리 단단하지는 않아.

English (United States)(en-US): Will I gather back into a\nsphere? I was born as one.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 흩어진 다음 구의 형태로 다시\n뭉치게 될까? 난 그런 성질이니까.

English (United States)(en-US): An amusing hypothesis, <nickname>. It’s\nrefreshing to see me through your eyes.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 재미있는 묘사네, <nickname>. 네 머릿속\n나는 어떤 이미지인지 느껴져서 즐거워.

English (United States)(en-US): Hm. hm, hm. I’ll tell you\nwhat I think will happen.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 음, 음, 음. 이쯤에서 나의 추측을 말해볼게.

English (United States)(en-US): If I drop, I will plunge into\nan ocean of emptiness.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 떨어진다면, 나는 공허의 바다를 잠수하게 될 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): It will be dismal. As if my body has melted\nin the saltwater and dispersed.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아주 비참할 거야. 내 육신이 바닷물에\n모두 녹아 조각조각 흩어지는 기분일 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Um… Sure you’re talking about a simple\ndrop? Did something happen today?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그냥 떨어지기만 하는 게 아닌 것\n같은데… 오늘 무슨 일이 있었던 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): Of course. What you’ll hear now is much\nmore essential than any hypothesis.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 물론이지. 묘사를 넘어 더욱 중요한 걸 알려줄게.

English (United States)(en-US): Humans seem to call such a story a tragedy.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 인간들은 이런 이야기를 비극이라고 부른다지?

English (United States)(en-US): It’s definitely… close to a tragedy.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 확실히… 비극에 가까워.

English (United States)(en-US): His dismal feelings were flaming like a torch.\nI could see some people being rapt by them.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그의 비참한 심정이 횃불처럼 타오르고 있었어.\n누군가는 매료될지도 모른다는 생각이 들 정도로.

English (United States)(en-US): Then a thought crept into my mind.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고 난 깨달아 버린 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): ‘Perhaps I could do something for this man.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘나라면 그에게 뭔가를 해줄 수\n있지 않을까?’하고 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): You? What could you do for him?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치가? 어떤 걸 해 줄 수 있다는 건데?

English (United States)(en-US): There is one circle he has yet to swallow.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 세상의 모든 동그라미를 삼킨 그가, 미처\n삼키지 못한 동그라미가 하나 있잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): And that is…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그건 바로…

English (United States)(en-US): It is I.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 바로 나.

English (United States)(en-US): This dream was essentially a journey to find\na circle that would fit an intrinsic fissure.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이 꿈은 고유한 균열에 꼭 맞는\n동그라미를 찾기 위한 여정이었잖아?

English (United States)(en-US): I thought, with my flexible and viscous body,\nI could fill it better than anything else.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 몸이 유연하고 끈적한 나라면 그 무엇보다도\n완벽하게 채워줄 수 있었을 것만 같았거든.

English (United States)(en-US): What’s more, I gather back into a beach ball\nshape after scattering like a bunch of pebbles!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 게다가 난 조약돌처럼 흩어진 다음에도,\n비치 볼처럼 다시 뭉쳐 버린다고?

English (United States)(en-US): Wow, if it’s you, perhaps it’s possible.|If we split you into two, would there be two Dots?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 우와, 정말 뭉치라면 가능한 일일지도?|그럼 갈라 놓으면 두 개의 뭉치가 될 수도 있는 걸까?

English (United States)(en-US): Right? You agree that I’ll somehow\nfit into the hole, <nickname>, right?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇지? <nickname>. 네 생각에도\n그럴듯하게 들어맞을 것 같지?

English (United States)(en-US): Huh? Hm? Mm?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어? 응? 으음? 흐음?

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe… Most possibly… Not. I’ll always be\nthe one and only Dot you know, <nickname>.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 렇 지 는 않 을 걸? 난 언제까지나 <nickname>,\n네가 알고 있는 유일무이 뭉치일 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Mm… I hope.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아마도… 음… 제발.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s decided. From now on, I’ll start\ntraining to fulfill his ardent wish.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 결심했어. 그의 간절한 소망을 이뤄\n주기 위해 지금부터라도 단련할 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): First up, I’ll practice staying stuck\nsomewhere for a long time.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 따라서 허공에 붙은 채로 버티는 연습을 해 보겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): Don’t you have the perfect space\nfor that in your room, <nickname>?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): <nickname>의 방에 마침 딱 알맞은 공간이 하나 있지?

English (United States)(en-US): Under the bed|In the bookshelf|On the ceiling|Outside the window
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 침대 밑|책장 속|천장 표면|창문 밖

English (United States)(en-US): Under the bed or On the\nceiling or Outside the window
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아!

English (United States)(en-US): It sounds good but I’m looking for\nsomewhere more adequate.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그것도 좋지만 더욱 적당한 공간을 하나 찾았으니까.

English (United States)(en-US): In the bookshelf?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 책장 속?

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, yes! That’s it! My corner.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 응! 바로 그거야! 나의 모퉁이.

English (United States)(en-US): I’ll roll and stick myself to the bookshelf. I’ll\nbecome a perfect sphere… It’s what I do best.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 몸을 동그랗게 말아서 책장에 붙어 볼게. 난 완전한\n구가 될 거야… 뭉치는 건 가장 자신 있는 분야니까.

English (United States)(en-US): (Dot throws themself\nat the empty bookshelf.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (뭉치가 빈 책장 벽에 몸을 던졌다.)

English (United States)(en-US): (Oh… Dot drops.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (앗… 떨어졌다.)

English (United States)(en-US): It can’t be. It can’t be. <nickname>,\nwill you stick me there once more?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이럴 리가 없는데. 이럴 리가 없는데.\n<nickname>, 날 다시 한 번만 붙여줄래?

English (United States)(en-US): (Stick Dot to the bookshelf wall.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (뭉치를 책장 벽에 붙여 주었다.)

English (United States)(en-US): (Oh… Dot drops.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (앗… 떨어졌다.)

English (United States)(en-US): Dot, don’t be too discouraged.|Do you want me to stick you one more time?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치야, 너무 실망하지 마.|다시 한 번 붙여 줄까?

English (United States)(en-US): I thought I could become a flawless sphere\nfor the man. Was all that a fantasy?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나라면 완전무결한 구가 되어줄 수 있을 것\n같았는데, 이게 다 잘못된 생각이었나?

English (United States)(en-US): He must have faced thousands of thorny roads.I thought I could be the one to lay one with clouds.He was facing countless thorny paths ahead.\nI thought I could be the one to ease his pain.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 수만 갈래의 가시밭길이 있었겠지. 하지만 나라면\n구름 길을 깔아 줄 수 있는 존재라고 느꼈는데.

English (United States)(en-US): Of course, someone else could do it. The\nworld is big and there is much I haven’t observed.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 물론 내가 아닌 다른 무언가일 수도 있겠지,\n세상은 넓고 내가 관측하지 못한 것들은 많으니까.

English (United States)(en-US): But he met me! I have a chance.\nIf not me, then who?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하지만 지금 나를 만났잖아! 지금 기회가 왔어.\n내가 하지 못하면 어느 누가 할 수 있을까?

English (United States)(en-US): Where will the poor man\nfinally take root and grow?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 가여운 그가 기어이 돋아날 곳은 어디일까?

English (United States)(en-US): Even with your body, it may have been\ndifficult to fill his hole entirely.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치의 몸통으로도 완벽하게\n채우는 건 힘든 일이었을지도 몰라.

English (United States)(en-US): Would he have done a sloppy job?\nNo way, it was such a desperate deficiency.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그가 일을 대충 했을까? 그리도 간절한 결핍이었는데.

English (United States)(en-US): He would have made all the circles he could.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 만들 수 있는 동그라미는 다 만들었겠지.

English (United States)(en-US): Even ones with stretchy and\nsticky material. For example…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 유연하고 끈적한 소재로도 만들어 봤을 거야, 가령…

English (United States)(en-US): No, he couldn’t have. A circle like me\ndoesn’t exist anywhere else on Earth.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇지 않아. 지구상에 나 같은\n동그라미는 어디에도 없었어.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m different from any earthly substance.\nNo thing could have better filled that man.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 달에서 온 나는 그 어떤 물질과도 달라. 나만큼 그\n인간을 완벽하게 채워줄 가능성이 있는 건 없었어.

English (United States)(en-US): As such, my failure is even more harsh to him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런 만큼 나의 실패는 그 인간에게\n더욱 가혹한 의미를 띄는 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m pathetic. Infernally\npathetic. I can’t deal with it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 한심해. 지옥 같이\n한심해. 견딜 수가 없다고.

English (United States)(en-US): Dot… But.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치야… 하지만.

English (United States)(en-US): (Feels like the hole in the logic\nshould be pointed out.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (맹점을 한번 짚어 주는 게 좋겠어.)

English (United States)(en-US): Perhaps you’ve overthought the ‘unknown substance’ part. |He never asked for your help. He doesn’t know you exist.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘미지의 물질’에 과하게 의미를 부여하는 건 아닐까.|그는 도움을 청한 적 없어, 뭉치의 존재를 모르잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): You’re made up of unknown substance, that’s it.\nYou couldn’t stick somewhere, but so what?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 달에서 온 너는 그저 미지의 물질이었어. 허공에서\n버티는 성질은 없다고 밝혀졌지만 그뿐이야.

English (United States)(en-US): I think you thought about it so\nmuch that you pressured yourself.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치가 너무 많은 의미를 부여하려다\n보니 너조차 힘들어진 게 아닌가 싶네.

English (United States)(en-US): Even without you, there are many other circles\nin the world. Circles he haven’t discovered yet.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치가 아니더라도 세상엔 다른 동그라미들이\n많을 거야. 그가 아직 발견하지 못한 모든 것들이.

English (United States)(en-US): So it may be a little early to feel guilty.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러니 죄책감을 갖는 게 조금은 이를지도 모르겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): Were there too many leaps in my logic?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 비약으로 느껴졌어?

English (United States)(en-US): A little.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래, 조금은 비약이었지.

English (United States)(en-US): Nonetheless, I hope you continue\nto pay attention to your kind heart.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하지만 너의 다정한 심성까지도\n외면하지 않았으면 좋겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): Thank you, <nickname>…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래, 고마워… <nickname>.

English (United States)(en-US): I could just melt from the embarrassment.\nWas I, a monster, too nosy in human business?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 부끄러워서 녹아 버릴 것 같아. 괴물인 내가\n인간에게 부적절하게 참견하려고 한 걸까?

English (United States)(en-US): Not really, other people may feel the same.|No, this is between two beings, not a person and a monster.Well, it's not just a story limited to monsters.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 글쎄, 인간끼리도 비슷한 마음을 품을 수 있는 걸.|아니, 인간과 괴물을 넘어 개체와 개체 간 이야기니까.

English (United States)(en-US): Other people feel the same? Then how do humans\nact when they see the emptiness in somebody?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나만의 이야기가 아니라는 거야? 그럼 인간들은\n누군가의 빈 자리를 발견하면 어떻게 행동해?

English (United States)(en-US): To see someone’s empty heart and feel pity\nmay be pretty common for us too.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 누군가의 비어 있는 마음을 보고 가련함을\n느끼는 건 우리에게도 꽤나 흔한 일일지 몰라.

English (United States)(en-US): Amid the euphoria of having been invited to\na unique room, sometimes we act unlike ourselves.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 하나뿐인 특별한 방에 초대되었다는 도취감에 사로잡힌\n채, 평소의 나답지는 않은 일을 벌이기도 하지.

English (United States)(en-US): Like you did just then.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 꼭 지금의 뭉치처럼 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Deficiency… Is it in every human? A hole in\ntheir heart, invisible to my chalk-drawn eyes?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 결핍이란 건 모든 인간이 가지고 있는 거야? 분필로\n그린 눈으로는 볼 수 없는 마음의 빈 자리가.

English (United States)(en-US): Everyone is born with a hole.|Everyone ends up with a hole.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 모두는 빈 자리를 가진 채로 태어나.|모두는 살아가면서 마음에 빈 자리를 마련해.

English (United States)(en-US): Which one are you?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너는 어느 쪽이야?

English (United States)(en-US): Do you have an unquenchable\nthirst for something too?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너에게도 채워지지 않는 갈증이 있어?

English (United States)(en-US): If I have a deficiency…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나에게도 결핍이 있다면…

English (United States)(en-US): Thank you for telling me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 들려 줘서 고마워.

English (United States)(en-US): Although it’s becoming increasingly embarrassing\nthat I’ve shown that ugly side of me…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런 너에게 추태를 보인 것 같아서\n더 창피해지려고 하지만….

English (United States)(en-US): Don’t worry about it too much, Dot.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 너무 신경 쓰지 마, 뭉치.

English (United States)(en-US): Okay, okay. I’m a little better now.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 응. 지금은 좀 괜찮아.

English (United States)(en-US): But I’m still not sure how I feel right now. I\nneed time to dwell on everything, word by word.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다만 내 마음이 어떤지 당장은 잘 모르겠어. 모든\n걸 마디마디 곱씹어 보는 시간이 필요한 것 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s time to rest now.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이제 조금 쉬어야겠다.

English (United States)(en-US): Thank you for imparting\nyour wisdom, <nickname>.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지혜를 나눠 줘서 고마워, <nickname>.

English (United States)(en-US): Is living as one’s empty self impossible?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 비워진 그대로는 살아갈 수 없는 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): For that person? Or all people?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 인간이? 아니면 모든 인간이?

English (United States)(en-US): Let’s start with that person. Then\nwe could reach Earth from the Moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그 인간부터 시작해 보고 싶어. 그러다 보면\n달에서 지구까지도 닿을 수 있을 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): (It must be some kind of idiom for starting small\nand gradually encompassing bigger concepts.)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (작게 시작해 점점 큰 개념을 포괄할\n수 있다는 일종의 관용어인 것 같아.)

English (United States)(en-US): Couldn’t he have stayed as he was?\nI thought his holey self was splendid.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 있는 그대로는 안 됐던 건가? 나는 구멍이 뚫린\n그의 모습이 아주 근사하다고 생각했거든.

English (United States)(en-US): If he were a storybook character,\nI would’ve named him ‘Ring Boy.’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 동화 속의 인물이었다면 난 ‘반지 소년’이라는\n이름을 붙여 주었을 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): Great name.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이름도 근사한 이름인 걸.

English (United States)(en-US): Why did Ring Boy want to be hole-less?\nSome people might want the opposite.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 반지 소년은 왜 구멍이 뚫리지 않은 상태가\n되고 싶어한 거야? 그 반대일 수도 있잖아.

English (United States)(en-US): I can guess… but it’s hard for me as\na stranger to give you a clear answer.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 추측 정도는 가능하지만… 타인인 내가 명쾌하게\n답해주기는 어려운 이야기인 것 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): How about this. Ask yourself a similar question.\nWhy do you dislike your black body so, Dot?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이렇게 해 볼까. 반대로 하는 거야. 뭉치는\n뭉치의 검은 몸을 싫어하는 이유가 뭐야?

English (United States)(en-US): Because…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그건…

English (United States)(en-US): Take your time.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 천천히 대답해 줘도 좋아.

English (United States)(en-US): Because I’m different from the dreams I’ve seen\non the Moon. I was the only black, colorless blob.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 달나라에서 본 꿈들과 나는 다르니까.\n나 혼자만 색채가 없는 시커먼 덩어리였으니까.

English (United States)(en-US): Ring Boy was also the only circular\nperson in a triangular family.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 반지 소년도 세모난 가족들 사이에서\n혼자만 동그라미로 태어난 사람이었지.

English (United States)(en-US): It can be hard to feel foreign within a society.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 사회 안에서 홀로 이질감을\n갖는다는 건 어려운 일이겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): And I imagine having a body shining with\ncolor. Becoming a beautifully shaped dream.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고 나는 색채로 빛나는 몸을 가지는 상상을 해.\n꿈이 되어 지금과는 다른 아름다운 형체를 갖는 꿈을.

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe Ring Boy desired his hole-less self as well.\nIf not triangular, he wanted to be flawless.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 반지 소년도 구멍이 뚫리지 않은 완전한 내가 되고\n싶었던 게 아닐까. 세모나진 못하더라도 파손되지는 않은.

English (United States)(en-US): If you yearn for an ideal version of yourself,\nyour current self dulls in comparison.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이상적인 나를 그리고 있다면\n지금의 나는 비교될 수밖에 없겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): Okay, although there’s more to it. I can’t discuss\n‘black’ with you yet. There’s an infested barrier.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래, 그것뿐만은 아니지만. ‘검정’에 대해서만큼은\n아직 너에게 말할 수 없어. 깊고 우글거리는 장벽이 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): (Dot’s ‘black’…)
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): (뭉치의 ’검정’에 대한 것…)

English (United States)(en-US): All right. I won’t press you. Mm… Do you\nunderstand Ring Boy now, though?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 알았어. 지금은 더 물어보지 않을게.\n음… 반지 소년에 대한 건 이해했어?

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, but how does a noble human share same\nideas with a monster like me? It’s hard to accept.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 하지만 고귀한 인간이 어떻게 나 같은 괴물과\n같은 생각을 하지?

English (United States)(en-US): Dot…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 쉽게 받아들이기 어려워.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s the truth. All people have a hole of\ntheir own, in different shapes and forms.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그게 정말인 걸. 대부분의 인간이 제각각의\n구멍을 조금씩은 가지고 있으니까 말이야.

English (United States)(en-US): … The human species not only\nhas colors but distinct stains.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): … 인간은 색채뿐만이 아니라 고유한\n얼룩도 가지고 있는 종족이구나.

English (United States)(en-US): Yes, so you see humans are not always great.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 인간이 마냥 근사하기만 한 건 아니거든.|우리를 이렇게나 멋지게 표현해 주다니 고맙네.

English (United States)(en-US): Can’t I keep saying that you all are amazing?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 혹시 계속 너희가 근사하다고 하면 안 돼?

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe tone it down just a leeetle bit.|If you feel that way… Sure.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 조금, 아주 조금은 자제해 줄래? 실은 부담스러워.|뭉치가 그렇게 느낀다면야… 괜찮아.

English (United States)(en-US): Okay, I will.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 응응. 그럴게.

English (United States)(en-US): Should we get back on\ntrack? Where were we?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그럼 다시 원래 이야기로 돌아와\n볼까? 어디까지 얘기했지?

English (United States)(en-US): The strange effects of ‘deficiency.’\nSo we’re back where we started.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): ‘결핍’의 기이한 부분에 대해.\n결국 처음으로 돌아오게 되겠네.

English (United States)(en-US): Whether Ring Boy could\nhave lived with his hole?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 반지 소년은 비워진 그대로는 살아갈 수 없는가?

English (United States)(en-US): Yes. Why did he fill it when it made him dismiss\nhis original identity, his original path of life?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 응, 그가 고유하게 태어난 모습과, 그가 고유하게 살아온\n궤적을 외면하면서까지 그걸 메우려는 이유가 뭐야?

English (United States)(en-US): Perhaps it was destructive behavior intended\nto damage the original ring shape.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어쩌면 그건 고유의 반지 모양을 훼손하려는\n파괴적인 행동이었을지도 몰라.

English (United States)(en-US): Ring Boy’s hole was already a part of him.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 반지 소년의 구멍은 이미 그의 일부니까.

English (United States)(en-US): You think there isn’t a way\nto get rid of a deficiency?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그럼 뭉치는 결핍은 없앨 방법이 없다고 보는 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): If that’s the goal, you would have to eliminate\none’s past, which would be a catastrophe. So no.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 없애는 것이 목표라면 과거를 통으로 들어내야 하겠지.\n그러려면 탈이 날 거야. 그러니 없앨 순 없어.

English (United States)(en-US): It’s like a deep scar. New tissue may cover the\nscar or it may fade, but it never disappears.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 패인 흉터 같은 거야. 그 자리에 있다가 새 살이 돋거나\n흐려질 수는 있겠지만, 아예 사라지지는 않아.

English (United States)(en-US): Wouldn’t it be better to accept a\ndeficiency as a ‘mark of one’s path?’
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 결핍은 ‘궤적이 남아 있는 모양’으로\n받아들이는 편이 이롭지 않을까.

English (United States)(en-US): Even dismissed history once was…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 외면한 역사도 사실이니까....

English (United States)(en-US): I see. But life goes on. What should I do\nwhen I want to overcome my scars?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇구나. 하지만 삶은 계속 펼쳐지는 걸. \n흉터를 극복하고 싶어지면 어떻게 해야 할까.

English (United States)(en-US): I think…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그건……

English (United States)(en-US): We’ll have to listen to you,\nthe one with the wisdom.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이미 지혜로운 너의 마음을 들어봐야 하겠네.

English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>. How do you\nhandle your own thirst?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): <nickname>. 너는 너의 갈증을\n어떻게 견뎌 나가고 있어?

English (United States)(en-US): Truthfully, it’s still painful.|I’m brainstorming ideas to relieve it.|I live with it as a part of myself.|It’s been so long, I stopped thinking about it.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 실은 아직도 고통스러워.|보완할 방법을 궁리하고 있어.|나의 일부로서 안고 살아가.|오래되어 자연스레 생각하지 않게 되었어.

English (United States)(en-US): I feel proud of you. Although a creature like\nme couldn’t possibly feel that way for a human.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어쩐지 너에게 기특하다는 말을 해주고 싶네. 실제로\n나 같은 게 인간에게 그런 감정을 느낄 수는 없겠지만.

English (United States)(en-US): Enduring what can only be endured.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 견뎌야만 견뎌지는 것들.

English (United States)(en-US): Embracing what can only be embraced.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 안고 지내야만 안을 수 있는 것들.

English (United States)(en-US): Accepting all that, I hope one day you’ll\nbe able to adore your singular identity.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그렇게 받아들인 채로 어느 순간에는 너의 단일한\n정체성을 사랑스러워해 줄 수 있길 바랄게.

English (United States)(en-US): This is what you wanted to say\nfrom the beginning, isn’t it?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭉치는 처음부터 이 이야기를 하고 싶었던 거구나.

English (United States)(en-US): Maybe.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그랬던 걸지도 몰라.

English (United States)(en-US): Ring Boy as well.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그리고 반지 소년도.

English (United States)(en-US): That’ll happen, I’m sure.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 분명 그렇게 될 거야.

English (United States)(en-US): So, have you accepted your\n‘black body’ as a shape now?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그럼, 이제 뭉치도 뭉치의 ‘검은 몸’은\n모양으로 받아들이기도 한 거야?

English (United States)(en-US): If you were a monster in a\nfairytale, I would name you…
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 네가 동화 속의 괴물이라면 난 이런 이름을 붙일래…

English (United States)(en-US): <nickname>.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): <nickname>.

English (United States)(en-US): My name is ‘Dot’ and… deficiencies\nand scars are different.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 이름은 ‘뭉치’고… 결핍과 결함은 다른 이야기야.

English (United States)(en-US): Thank you for handing out your kindness.\nI’ll keep it in my heart and think it over.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 친절을 나눠 줘서 고마워.\n품을 들여 곱씹어 보도록 할게.
